findings:
- Cardiomegaly with prominent cardiac silhouette.
- Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates with patchy opacities predominantly in the lower lung zones.
- Pleural effusions bilaterally, more pronounced on the right side.
- Evidence of central venous catheter placement with tubing coursing into the superior vena cava.
- Presence of a transvenous pacemaker with leads visible in the right atrium and ventricle.
- Mildly displaced mediastinum with slight deviation to the left.
- No obvious pneumothorax or rib fractures.
- Diaphragm appears elevated, particularly on the right side.
- No visible lung nodules or masses.
- Abdominal organs are partially obscured by the overlying cardiac silhouette and fluid.
impression:
- Likely acute exacerbation of heart failure with pulmonary edema.
- Bilateral pleural effusions secondary to cardiac dysfunction.
- Possible right-sided tension or large pleural effusion contributing to mediastinal shift.
- Patient has a history of cardiac device implantation (pacemaker) and central venous access, consistent with chronic cardiac disease.
- No evidence of acute pulmonary embolism or pneumonia on this imaging.
- Consideration of diuretic therapy and further cardiac evaluation.
full_response:
Findings: - Cardiomegaly with prominent cardiac silhouette.
- Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates with patchy opacities predominantly in the lower lung zones.
- Pleural effusions bilaterally, more pronounced on the right side.
- Evidence of central venous catheter placement with tubing coursing into the superior vena cava.
- Presence of a transvenous pacemaker with leads visible in the right atrium and ventricle.
- Mildly displaced mediastinum with slight deviation to the left.
- No obvious pneumothorax or rib fractures.
- Diaphragm appears elevated, particularly on the right side.
- No visible lung nodules or masses.
- Abdominal organs are partially obscured by the overlying cardiac silhouette and fluid.
Impression: - Likely acute exacerbation of heart failure with pulmonary edema.
- Bilateral pleural effusions secondary to cardiac dysfunction.
- Possible right-sided tension or large pleural effusion contributing to mediastinal shift.
- Patient has a history of cardiac device implantation (pacemaker) and central venous access, consistent with chronic cardiac disease.
- No evidence of acute pulmonary embolism or pneumonia on this imaging.
- Consideration of diuretic therapy and further cardiac evaluation.
